The facility has established a Mechanical Integrity program to assure that equipment used to process, store, or handle ammonia is designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of ammonia releases. A mechanical integrity program is in place to assure the continued integrity of ammonia equipment.  A maintenance schedule was compiled to track and log the process.

The Hot Work Permit is to control, in a consistent manner, non-routine work conducted in ammonia process areas. Specifically, this subparagraph is concerned with the permitting of hot work operations in process areas. Hot work permits for hot work operations, such as the ones associated with welding and cutting conducted on or near an ammonia process, will be in compliance with the fire prevention and protection requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a).

Management of Change is intended to require management of all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions concerning ammonia other than replacement in kind, by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation.

An incident investigation will be performed any time there is an incident which results in, or which could reasonably have resulted in (near-miss), a catastrophic release of ammonia. A catastrophic release can be defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving ammonia that presents serious danger to employees, including contract employees working on-site.

Boskovich Farms, Inc. has developed a compliance audit program to verify implementation of all PSM elements. The aud

its are conducted at least every three years. A Compliance Audit Checklist will be used to conduct and document the audit. The audits are performed on the ammonia facilities and the lead verifies that the audit records are included in the PSM Files.  A written report of the audit findings is prepared.  Responses to the audit findings are promptly addressed and documented, and any deficiencies found during the audit promptly corrected.  Once the audit form is completed, the appropriate actions to address the recommendations are taken and documented.


Five-Year Accident History
For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR §2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under §2745.5, §2745.6, and §2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under §2745.10, whichever is earlier.  19 CCR §2750.9 states: The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

The Boskovich Farms facility has had no releases in the last five years that meets the five-year accident history reporting criteria. 


Emergency Response Program
Boskovich Farms, is a non-responding facility and does not train employees for active responses to ammonia releases.  This facility will rely upon the local emergency hazardous materials response team and the LA County Fire Department for responses to uncontrolled releases of anhydrous ammonia.  In accordance with 19 CCR §2765.1, the facility is not required to have an Emergency Response Plan in place.  However, it is required to have appropriate mechanisms in place for notifying emergency responders when there is a need for response.  These mechanisms are described below.

Accidental Release Prevention
Boskovich Farms has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System. Boskovich Farms policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The Boskovich Farms facility is listed as 711 Diaz Avenue, Oxnard, California 93030.  The regulated substance managed at the facility is anhydrous ammonia.  For documenting purposes, the facility will report the maximum intended inventory as 27,870 pounds (lbs.) of anhydrous ammonia. Refer to Process Safety Information section for related ammonia inventory calculations and information.


Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
In accordance with CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the Ammonia Refrigeration System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the CalARP Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook (Compliance Workbook).

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
An alternative release scenario was modeled in accordance with applicable regulations.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the Compliance Workbook.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Boskovich Farms has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it sho

uld also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event. In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release include a well-designed relief system, alarms and shutoffs, gas detection, and an adequate venting system.


Accidental Release Prevention Program
As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Boskovich Farms to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed. The facility maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 27,870 lbs.  Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 500-lbs. state threshold for the CalARP Program.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3 requirements.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:
- Process Safety Information
- Process Hazard Analysis [PHA]
- Operating Procedures
- Training
- Mechanical Integrity
- Management of Change
- Pre-Startup Safety Review
- Compliance Audits
- Incident Investigation
- Employee Participation
- Hot Work Permit
- Contractors

The purpose of employee participation is improved safety for all employees. PSM will not be effective without the involvement of the employees and/or their representatives.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. provides for employee participation in their process safety management plans by consulting with employees in developing the PSM program. 

Each new refrigeration employee is made aware of ammonia refrigeration PSM as a part of their initial orientation process, in conju

he facility has submitted a Hazardous Material Inventory (HMI) via California Environmental Reporting System (CERS).  In addition, the Business Emergency Plan (BEP) has been filed with the local Fire Department.  The HMI and BEP are located with the Plant Manager. The facility has procedures in-place to evacuate the facility and notify responders when there is a need for a response.  A current copy of the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) can be found with the Plant Manager, and within the Emergency Planning and Response tab of the Compliance Workbook.  The EAP includes emergency alarm procedures, evacuation procedures, safety and health considerations, and notification procedures.

The PSM document is a simple explanation of what the PSM program for ammonia refrigeration is all about.  It is reviewed with each new refrigeration employee and they acknowledge their awareness of PSM by signing the document.  If necessary, the PSM orientation is given in Spanish.  PSM awareness documents are available in both English and in Spanish.

Boskovich Farms, Inc. involves operations or maintenance employees in meetings or discussions concerning the PSM policies and procedures.  In addition, several other PSM procedures are reviewed by or conducted with the involvement of at least one employee or a representative of the employees:
- Process Safety Information is reviewed for accuracy and thoroughness.
- Operating Procedures are developed with input from refrigeration employees. In addition, refrigeration employees check the written procedures to ensure they are accurate.
- Training programs and needs for refresher training are reviewed with affected employees. More experienced refrigeration employees participate in the training process by observing the demonstration of job tasks conducted by the less experienced employees.
- Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are conducted with involvement of at least one refrigeration employee.
- Mechanical Integrity Audits are conducted with the involvement of at least one refrigeration employee.
- Refrigeration employees participate in the development of the mechanical integrity program and procedures.
- All affected refrigeration employees are made aware of ammonia refrigeration process changes prior to commencement of work. 
- Incident Investigation reports are reviewed with all affected refrigeration employees. An employee may be asked to serve on the investigation team.
- Emergency Planning and Response procedures are

reviewed with affected employees.

Boskovich Farms, Inc. also provides a means of allowing employees to voice concerns about process safety to management. To meet this provision, we have established a management system to address, resolve, follow-up and document employee concerns.  This management system includes provisions to:
- Assure that the concerns are resolved in a timely manner.
- Document the actions that are to be taken to resolve the concerns.
- complete the actions as soon as possible; when necessary, interim measures are taken when the
- Actions will require significant time to implement.
- Develop a written schedule of when actions are to be completed.
- Monitor the implementation of the actions and verify and document their completion.
- communicate the actions to operating, maintenance, and other employees whose work
- Assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

Refrigeration employees, including contractor refrigeration employees, are provided access to the PHA and any other information required by the PSM Standard. They have access to all PSI, including piping and instrumentation drawings (P&IDs), equipment information, chemical information such as SDS, technological information such as process chemistry, and operating and maintenance procedures.

The PSM RMP Coordinator is responsible for controlling access to PSM information. All affected employees are provided access to ammonia refrigeration PSM files and information at all times (not just during day shift) but access is available under the following limitations:
- Approval must be given to remove any documents from the file.
- Original copies of documents are not to be removed from the file area.
- No markings are be made on original documents.
- Previously unfiled documents are only added with proper authorization.

The PSM Standard requires employers to perform a PHA for the covered ammonia refrigeration process. The purpose

of performing a PHA is to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the process and to provide information to assist employers in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the chances of a catastrophic ammonia release. The PHA was performed by teams with expertise in engineering and process operations, knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology used, and included employees with experience and knowledge specific to the processes being evaluated.

The intent of Operating Procedures is to provide clear instructions for conducting activities involved in handling ammonia that are consistent with the process safety information. The operating procedures address steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.

Training has been developed to help employees understand the nature and causes of problems arising from ammonia operations, and increase employee awareness with respect to their hazards. An effective training procedure significantly reduces the number and severity of incidents arising from process operations, and can be instrumental in preventing small problems from leading to a catastrophic release. The training procedures include: Initial Training, Refresher Training, and Documentation.

The contractors screening process is designed to evaluate the desired job tasks involving ammonia without compromising the safety and health of employees at a facility. The contractor must assure that contract employees are trained on performing the job safely, on the hazards related to the job, and on applicable provisions of the emergency action plan.
